Beto O’Rourke, who is challenging Republican incumbent Greg Abbott in the Texas governor’s race, had previously demanded Joe Biden end Title 42, arguing that the pandemic-era border restrictions create an “incentive to cross [the border] in between ports of entry.” But when the Biden administration announced it would do just that, the El Paso Democrat said the restrictions should stay in place until Biden's team produces a plan to deal with the anticipated surge at the border when it is lifted.

Wisconsin Lieutenant Governor Mandela Barnes, the leading Democrat seeking to flip Republican Ron Johnson’s Senate seat in November, also urged Biden not to lift the restrictions May 23 without “a detailed plan in place so that we can keep asylum seekers and people in the country safe.”
“I’d like to see Biden put forward a comprehensive plan that deals with an influx of asylum seekers before we lift Title 42,” Barnes told the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel in an interview Tuesday.

“We need a secure, orderly, and humane response at our southern border and our bipartisan legislation holds the Biden administration accountable to that.” Conservative Democrat Joe Manchin seemingly went even further, and said Title 42 should stay in place until Congress passes “comprehensive, bipartisan immigration reform” — a policy area Republicans and Democrats have failed to reach consensus on for more than a decade and have only moved further apart on in recent years.

“I have yet to hear a plan from the Biden administration to address the dynamic we will have on the border once Title 42 ends.”
The Biden administration’s decision last month to terminate the Title 42 border restrictions Donald Trump imposed at the beginning of the pandemic triggered predictable backlash from the right, where some prominent GOP leaders used the announcement as an opportunity to score political points with the base.

The comments from O’Rourke and Barnes, who are taking on two of the most prominent Trumpists, came days after Arizona Senator Kyrsten Sinema, a conservative Democrat, and Oklahoma Senator James Lankford, a Republican, introduced legislation seeking a border plan before the Trump order is rescinded.
